DOI: 10.1016/S1872-2067(10)60118-0 SURVEY PAPER Monolayer-Protected Gold Nanoparticle Surface-Bound Catalysts: Preparation and Application JIA Lifeng, HE Tao*, LI Zhipeng, LI Xue-Mei* State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing 210009, Jiangsu, China Abstract: Precious metal nanomaterials have shown significantly different reactivity and catalytic activity because of their small-size ef- fects. In this report, we focused on gold nanoparticle-based catalysts, especially gold nanoparticle surface-bound catalysts, their preparation and application. Because of its special surface properties, gold can form stable bonds with sulfur containing molecules including sulfides and thiols. These molecules form well ordered self-assembled monolayers on gold nanoparticles, which render monolayer-protected gold nanoparticles (MPGs) with good solubility, easy characterization, extraordinary stability, and versatility. With attached functional groups, we used MPGs as surface-bound catalysts. These catalysts show the combined characteristics of a homogeneous and a heterogeneous catalyst, which is critical for theoretical aspects and in the development of new types of surface-bound catalysts. Key words: gold nanoparticle; coordination catalysis; heterogeneous catalysis; surface-bound catalyst The preparation and application of monolayer-protected gold nanoparticles (MPGs) is a novel interdisciplinary area [1–3]. Because of the very strong gold-sulfur interaction [4], gold nanoparticles are very stable after coated with thiols by the formation of self-assembled monolayers (SAM), which render the MPGs with good dispersibility and solubility in a certain solvent [5]. Because of their nanometer size, MPGs show small size effects, especially quantized size effects [6] and surface effects. The surface effects are expressed by that surface functional groups determine their solubility [7], reac- tivity [2,8–10], biocompatibility [11,12], and catalytic activity [2]. It is noteworthy that the catalytic activities are mainly because of the surface-bound catalytically active functional groups. Owing to the high surface-to-volume ratio of the nanoparticles, these colloid-bound catalysts exhibit higher catalytic efficiency than their homogeneous counterparts. Moreover, these surface-bound catalysts show the characteris- tics of both homogeneous catalysts and heterogeneous cata- lysts. Specifically, the surface-bound catalysts can be well dispersed in a solvent just like a homogeneous catalyst but can also be recovered by precipitation and centrifugation. There- fore, the preparation and application of these catalysts are an interesting subject. Because there have been limited reviews in this area, we summarize previous work and recent progress with a special focus on nanoparticle preparation, surface func- tionalization, and application in catalysis in this report. 1 Preparation of MPGs and introduction of functional ligands to MPGs 1.1 Preparation of MPGs Gold nanoparticles tend to aggregate due to their high sur- face energy. It has been a challenge to prepare gold nanoparti- cles with good dispersibility and uniform size until Schmid reported in 1981 for the first time a type of ligand-protected gold nanocluster, Au 55 [PPh 3 ] 12 Cl 6 [3,13,14]. This gold nano- cluster has a double-layer structure with a gold core consisting of 55 gold atoms and an outer layer of 12 chlorine and 6 triphenylphosphine ligands. This ligand-protected gold cluster is uniform in size and is chemically very stable, but its prepa- ration involves typical organometallic synthesis. In 1998, Brust JIA Lifeng et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2010, 31: 1307–1315 et al. [5] reported a two phase preparation of monolayer pro- tected gold nanoparticles (Scheme 1). This process involves the use of a phase transfer reagent tetraoctyammonia bromide to transfer the tetrachloroaurate ligand from water into toluene, which is then reduced by NaBH 4 in the presence of dodecane thiol. Although the resulting MPGs are not as uniform in size as those of Schmid, particles of various sizes ranging from 1.5 to 20 nm were prepared according to this method. 1.2 Introduction of functional ligands to MPGs Brust’s method is a two-phase method, and most products are lipophilic with the outer functional groups determining the final solubility and reactivity of the MPGs. Moreover, because of their small size, these MPGs can be characterized just like common chemical compounds. Many characterization meth- ods are applicable including NMR [5], infrared spectroscopy [15], ultraviolet spectroscopy, and mass spectrometry [7,16]. Moreover, MPGs show quantized effects [17], small size ef- fects, and surface effects. Surface effects are of special rele- vance because the surface functional groups determine their solubility, reactivity, and even catalytic activity. Based on Brust’s method, a wide variety of thiols with chain lengths of C 3 –C 24 [1], dialkyldisulfides [18], dendrimers [19–21], and thiolated polyethylene glycol (PEG) [22,23] have been used as coating ligands for MPG preparation. There have also been reports on the use of other ligands including amides [24] and iron carbonyls [25]. Other methods for the preparation of MPGs include microfluidic [26], microwave [27], and elec- trochemical methods [28]. Gold nanoparticles, however, are usually prepared by citrate or succinic acid reduction [29]. Currently, the preparation methods are rather versatile but the control of monodispersity and the attachment of desired func- tional groups are still major challenges [30]. Compared with thiols, thioether interacts less strongly with gold but it is chemically more stable. Moreover, when multiple attachment points exist in a molecule, for example, the pres- ence of many thioether end groups, a well-ordered SAM can still be formed on gold, for example, the thioether derivatives of calix arene and -cyclodextrin [31–33]. In 2001, Li et al. [34] reported the use of thioethers as protecting ligands for MPGs. The molecular structures of the series of thioethers used are shown in Scheme 2 with 1–4 thioether ligands and different head functional groups. Results show that compared to thiols, thioethers also yield gold nanoparticles but with shorter time stability. The combination of rigid headgroups and multiple attachment points afford gold nanoparticles with comparable stability to thiolated MPGs. Hasan et al. [35] made use of this weak gold thioether interaction to study the ligand exchange process of a thioether with dodecanethiol and monitored the Scheme 1. Brust’s synthesis of monolayer-protected gold nanoclusters (MPGs) [5]. Molecular structure of the thioethers used for MPG formation [34]. JIA Lifeng et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2010, 31: 1307–1315 exchange by 1 H NMR, which provided a powerful proof of the fate of hydrogen in RS-H during the SAM formation on gold. The introduction of functional groups, especially catalyti- cally active functional groups, is critical in the preparation of a surface-bound catalyst. A prerequisite for the ligand is that it must have a thiol moiety. It is well known that sulfur can form a complex with many transition metals that constitute the major components of catalysts. Therefore, it has been a challenge to introduce a complex catalyst to a gold nanoparticle surface. Two representative methods have been developed to introduce functional groups to MPGs: place-exchange as developed by Hostetler et al. [9] and mixed ligands as developed by Friggeri et al. [36]. In a typical place-exchange approach, MPGs capped with an alkanethiol prepared using Brust’s method are placed in a solvent containing the desired functional thiol. During the exchange process, the surface thiolate desorbs and makes place for the thiol in solution, which then adsorbs onto the gold nanoparticle surface. The advantage of this process is that a broad range of end functional groups are available. Although many end-functional groups can be introduced to the surface of gold, this method suffers from difficulties in controlling the degree of exchange. Moreover, the steric hin- drance of bulky groups, hydrogen bonding, ionic strength of the exchange solution, and pH of the solution affect the ex- change process. Irreversible aggregation can also result in some cases. In the mixed ligand approach, Friggeri et al. [36] used the desired molar ratio of the initial mixture of thiols to prepare MPGs. Decanethiol and mercapto-11-undecanethiol were used in a 4:1 ratio to prepare MPGs providing a simple method to obtain MPGs with mixed functional groups. More- over, analysis demonstrated that the final product had the same molar ratio of ligands as the initial ratio. By further esterifica- tion of the hydroxyl end groups with 4-(diphenylphosphino) benzoic acid, triphenylphosphine functionalized MPGs were obtained, which might be useful for the preparation of a sur- face-bound Grubbs type of catalyst (Scheme 3). 2 Preparation of MPG surface-bound catalysts and their application Bartz et al. [38] reported the first preparation and catalytic activity of an MPG surface-bound catalyst for the ring-opening metathesis polymerization of norbornene. Bartz et al. used the Scheme 3. Use of a decanethiol and 11-hydroxy-undecanethiol mixture as ligands for the preparation of MPGs and coupling to 4-(diphenylphosphino) benzoic acid [36,37]. JIA Lifeng et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2010, 31: 1307–1315 thiol derivative of hexadiene as a protecting ligand for gold nanoparticles, which were then reacted with RuCl 3 to form a hexadiene-Ru complex, similar to the well known metathesis catalyst (Scheme 4). They found that the surface-bound cata- lyst catalyzed the ring-opening polymerization of norbornene with much higher catalytic efficiency. They suggested that the orientation of the catalyst on the surface facilitates its interac- tion with the monomer and the growth of the polymer chain. It is noteworthy that in the catalytic process, the MPGs were well dispersed in the reaction mixture and they showed the charac- teristics of a homogeneous catalyst. After the completion of the reaction, the MPGs were recovered by precipitation, which is typical of a heterogeneous catalyst. The results of Bartz et al. are very interesting but the preparation of the surface-bound catalyst requires organometallic chemistry, which limits its accessibility. Nevertheless, it has been demonstrated that these surface bound catalysts show the combined characteristics of both a homogeneous catalyst and a heterogeneous catalyst. Based on a place-exchange reaction, Li et al. [39] attached a dihydroxylation catalyst, which showed reactivity in the di- hydroxylation of aromatic olefins to yield chiral diols (Scheme 5). The catalytic reaction was carried out in an aqueous mixed solvent, where no exclusion of air or water was needed. Moreover, the catalytic reactivity of this surface-bound catalyst is similar to the polymer supported alkaloid ligands. Belser et al. [40] prepared a MPG surface-bound catalyst for the asymmetric hydrolysis of epoxy functional groups based on Co(III) (Scheme 6) also by a place-exchange approach. A thiol derivative of chiral salen was attached to a gold nanoparticle by place-exchange, which was then reacted with Co(II) acetate. Scheme 4. Gold nanoparticle surface-bound catalyst for olefin metathesis polymerization: the ligand used for colloid preparation, the homogeneous catalyst, and the surface-bound catalyst [38]. Scheme 5. Gold nanoparticle surface-bound catalyst and its application in the dihydroxylation of aromatic olefins [39]. JIA Lifeng et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2010, 31: 1307–1315 After oxidation, a catalytically active system was formed on the MPGs surface. Catalytic reaction tests showed that at a load of 0.01 mol%, a higher than 99.9% ee kinetic resolution was achieved over a reaction time of 5 h. For the catalyst without surface-attachment similar results could only be obtained for 0.1 mol% catalyst loading and a reaction time of 24 h. Ap- parently, the catalytic reactivity of the surface-bound catalyst is much better than the unbound catalyst with advantages of easy regeneration and recovery. In the Brust approach to prepare MPGs, a phase transfer reagent was used to transfer the aurate to the organic phase and the final product was lipophilic. Moreover, the phase transfer SH O Co(OAC) 2 ,TfOH,air Au O S S S S S S S S S S S S S t-BuHO N N OH t-Bu t-Bu Au S S S S S S S S S S S S S O O t-BuO N N Co O t-Bu t-Bu OS O O CF 3 O O t-Bu O N N Co O t-Bu t-Bu HO S O O CF 3 O O t-Bu N N O Co O t-Bu t-Bu OS O O CF 3 O O t-Bu O N N Co O t-Bu t-Bu OS O O CF 3 Scheme 6. Synthesis of a Co(III) containing MPG-based catalyst for the asymmetric hydrolysis of epoxy functional groups [40]. Scheme 7. Preparation of a sulfonic acid functionalized gold nanoparticle and its application in the hydrolysis of TMS silylether [41]. JIA Lifeng et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2010, 31: 1307–1315 reagent needs to be removed to yield a pure product. On the other hand, this method is not suitable for the preparation of water-soluble gold nanoparticles. In 2004, Li et al. [41] re- ported the preparation of water-soluble, sulfonated MPGs in a one-step approach. These particles showed reasonable catalytic reactivity. The MPGs were prepared by reduction of tetra- chloroauric acid in the presence of 5-mercapto- 2-benzimidazole sulfonate sodium salt (MBS) in water. Sul- fonic acid functionalized gold nanoparticles were obtained by ion exchange using a Dowex-H + ion exchanger. The sulfonic acid functionalized gold nanoparticles catalyzed the hydrolysis of trimethylsilylether (TMS) adsorbate in solution (Scheme 7). The MPGs were further applied as ink in a microcontact printing process, which catalyzed the hydrolysis of the TMS SAM selectively in the area of contact yielding patterned sur- faces of different functional groups [31,41]. Because gold nanoparticles have a similar geometric size as the tip of an atomic force microscope, these MPGs provided a powerful and easily monitored model system for later catalytic probe nano- lithography during nanofabrication (Scheme 8) [42]. 3 Conclusions We summarize recent developments in surface-bound cata- lysts based-on monolayer protected gold nanoparticles. Be- cause of their small size effects and surface effects, MPG sur- face-bound catalysts show characteristics of both a homoge- neous catalyst and a heterogeneous catalyst. Because of their high surface-to-volume ratio and possibly the cooperative effects of the gold nanoparticles, these catalysts show signifi- cantly higher catalytic efficiency than their homogeneous counterparts. These catalysts can also be used as model sys- tems to study the kinetics of a certain reaction, which may help in the development of new catalysts. References 1 Brust M, Kiely C J. SURVEY PAPER Monolayer-Protected Gold Nanoparticle Surface-Bound Catalysts: Preparation and Application Lifeng JIA Tao HE # Zhipeng LI Xue-Mei LI * State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Technology, Nanjing 210009, Jiangsu, China * Corresponding author. Tel/Fax: +86-25-83587775 # Corresponding author Precious metal nanomaterials have shown significantly different reactivity and catalytic activity because of their small-size effects. In this report, we focused on gold nanoparticle-based catalysts, especially gold nanoparticle surface-bound catalysts, their preparation and application. Because of its special surface properties, gold can form stable bonds with sulfur containing molecules including sulfides and thiols. These molecules form well ordered self-assembled monolayers on gold nanoparticles, which render monolayer-protected gold nanoparticles (MPGs) with good solubility, easy characterization, extraordinary stability, and versatility. With attached functional groups, we used MPGs as surface-bound catalysts. These catalysts show the combined characteristics of a homogeneous and a heterogeneous catalyst, which is critical for theoretical aspects and in the development of new types of surface-bound catalysts. 摘要 ：贵金属纳米粒子由于其小尺寸效应而表现出特殊的催化性能. 综述了纳米 Au 粒子表面配位催化剂的制备方法及其在催化中的应用. 由于 Au 可与硫化物形成配位键, 所以硫化物可在 Au 表面形成有序单分子膜. 单分子膜保护的 Au 纳米粒子具有非常好的溶解性、分散性、稳定性, 以及由不同的表面功能团而导致的不同的催化性能. 该催化体系兼具均相催化剂和多相催化剂的特点, 这对开发新型催化剂具有重要的理论和实际意义. Graphical abstract Monolayer-protected gold nanoparticles were applied as catalyst using ligands that are catalytically active. Results show that these surface-bound catalysts demonstrate significant catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: Precious metal nanomaterials have shown significantly different reactivity and catalytic activity because of their small-size effects. In this report, we focused on gold nanoparticle-based catalysts, especially gold nanoparticle surface-bound catalysts, their preparation and application. Because of its special surface properties, gold can form stable bonds with sulfur containing molecules including sulfides and thiols. These molecules form well ordered self-assembled monolayers on gold nanoparticles, which render monolayer-protected gold nanoparticles (MPGs) with good solubility, easy characterization, extraordinary stability, and versatility. With attached functional groups, we used MPGs as surface-bound catalysts. These catalysts show the combined characteristics of a homogeneous and a heterogeneous catalyst, which is critical for theoretical aspects and in the development of new types of surface-bound catalysts.
coredata.prism:publisher: Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Monolayer-Protected Gold Nanoparticle Surface-Bound Catalysts: Preparation and Application
